Operation 'DeleteSpamReports' has semantic quality issues: missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Current description lacks clarity on expected request body structure and response format. Added explicit details about the two input modes (delete_all boolean vs emails array), clarified the response behavior (success with no content), and reorganized for better AI agent comprehension of when and how to use this operation.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete your spam reports.**

Deleting a spam report will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed address. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.

There are two options for deleting spam reports: 

1. You can delete all spam reports by setting the `delete_all` field to `true` in the request body.
2. You can delete a list of select spam reports by specifying the email addresses in the `emails` array of the request body.
data.description_suggestion: Deletes spam report suppressions, removing the suppression status and allowing email delivery to previously suppressed addresses. Supports two deletion modes: (1) delete all spam reports by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body, or (2) delete specific spam reports by providing email addresses in the `emails` array. Deleting suppressions should only be done when recipients indicate they wish to receive email again. Returns a success response with no content. Note: Use bypass filters for exceptions rather than removing suppressions.
data.reasoning: Current description lacks clarity on expected request body structure and response format. Added explicit details about the two input modes (delete_all boolean vs emails array), clarified the response behavior (success with no content), and reorganized for better AI agent comprehension of when and how to use this operation.

Use this operation to check if a specific address has been marked as spam by recipients.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a specific spam report by email address.**

Deleting a spam report will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed address. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.
data.description_suggestion: Deletes a specific spam report suppression for a given email address, removing the suppression status and allowing email delivery to that address. Requires the email address as a path parameter. Returns a success response with no content. Deleting suppressions should only be done when recipients indicate they wish to receive email again. Side effect: The email address will no longer be suppressed and will receive future emails. Consider using bypass filters for exceptions rather than removing suppressions.
data.reasoning: Description lacks explicit details about the path parameter requirement and response format. Added clarity on the email parameter, specified the response behavior (success with no content), and explicitly documented the side effect of removing suppression status to help AI agents understand the operation's impact on system state.

message: Operation 'ListGlobalSuppression' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, inconsistent_terminology. Original description has a grammatical error ('email address' should be 'email addresses') and uses inconsistent terminology. The API context refers to 'suppressions' and 'unsubscribes' interchangeably, but this operation should clarify that global suppressions are equivalent to global unsubscribes. Enhanced description corrects grammar, clarifies the relationship between suppressions and unsubscribes, specifies response structure, and provides context for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a paginated list of all email address that are globally suppressed.**

You can use the `limit` query parameter to set the page size. If your list contains more items than the page size permits, you can make multiple requests. Use the `offset` query parameter to control the position in the list from which to start retrieving additional items.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a paginated list of all email addresses that are globally suppressed (unsubscribed from all emails). Supports pagination using `limit` (page size) and `offset` (starting position) query parameters. Returns an array of suppression records containing email addresses and suppression timestamps. Global suppressions represent recipients who have opted out of all email communications. Use this operation to audit your global unsubscribe list or check if specific addresses are globally suppressed.
data.reasoning: Original description has a grammatical error ('email address' should be 'email addresses') and uses inconsistent terminology. The API context refers to 'suppressions' and 'unsubscribes' interchangeably, but this operation should clarify that global suppressions are equivalent to global unsubscribes. Enhanced description corrects grammar, clarifies the relationship between suppressions and unsubscribes, specifies response structure, and provides context for AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'GetGlobalSuppression' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary 'Retrieve a Global Suppression' is generic and doesn't clarify the dual purpose (checking suppression status). Description is verbose and contains a typo ('suppresed'). Improved summary emphasizes the verification/checking action. Improved description clarifies the conditional response behavior and explains the practical use case for AI agents.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a global suppression. You can also use this endpoint to confirm if an email address is already globally suppresed.**

If the email address you include in the URL path parameter `{email}` is already globally suppressed, the response will include that email address. If the address you enter for `{email}` is not globally suppressed, an empty JSON object `{}` will be returned.
data.summary_suggestion: Check if an email address is globally suppressed
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the global suppression status for a specific email address. Returns the email address object if it is globally suppressed, or an empty JSON object `{}` if the address is not suppressed. Use this endpoint to verify whether an email address has been globally suppressed from all SendGrid messages.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Retrieve a Global Suppression' is generic and doesn't clarify the dual purpose (checking suppression status). Description is verbose and contains a typo ('suppresed'). Improved summary emphasizes the verification/checking action. Improved description clarifies the conditional response behavior and explains the practical use case for AI agents.

However, description conflates 'suppression group' with 'global suppressions' terminology and lacks clarity about the response. data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to remove an email address from the global suppressions group.**

Deleting a suppression group will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed addresses. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.
data.description_suggestion: Removes an email address from the global suppressions group, allowing emails to be sent to that address again. This operation should only be performed when a recipient explicitly requests to receive emails. Returns a 204 No Content response on successful deletion. Note: Use bypass filters for temporary exceptions rather than removing suppressions.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. However, description conflates 'suppression group' with 'global suppressions' terminology and lacks clarity about the response. Improved description clarifies the side effect (emails will be sent again), specifies the HTTP response code, and better explains when this operation should be used for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to remove email addresses from your invalid email address list.**

There are two options for deleting invalid email addresses: 

1) You can delete all invalid email addresses by setting `delete_all` to true in the request body.
2) You can delete some invalid email addresses by specifying certain addresses in an array in the request body.
data.summary_suggestion: Remove email addresses from invalid email list
data.description_suggestion: Removes one or more email addresses from the invalid email address list. Supports two deletion modes: (1) delete all invalid emails by setting `delete_all` to true, or (2) delete specific addresses by providing an array of email addresses in the request body. Returns a 204 No Content response on successful deletion. Deleted addresses will be eligible for sending again.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic ('Delete invalid emails'). Description explains the two deletion modes but lacks clarity about response and side effects. Improved summary is more action-oriented. Improved description clarifies the request body options, specifies the HTTP response code, and explains the side effect (addresses become eligible for sending) to help AI agents understand the operation's impact.

message: Operation 'DeleteSuppressionBounces' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary 'Delete bounces' is too generic and doesn't indicate the dual-mode functionality. Description lacks clarity about what is returned and doesn't explicitly state the mutual exclusivity constraint upfront. Enhanced summary specifies the operation supports both bulk and selective deletion. Enhanced description clarifies the mutually exclusive parameters, adds return value information, and improves AI agent understanding of when to use each deletion mode.

data.current_description:
This endpoint allows you to delete all emails on your bounces list.

There are two options for deleting bounced emails: 

1. You can delete all bounced emails by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body. 
2. You can delete a selection of bounced emails by specifying the email addresses in the `emails` array of the request body. 

**WARNING:** You can not have both `emails` and `delete_all` set.
data.summary_suggestion: Delete bounced emails by selection or bulk
data.description_suggestion: Removes email addresses from your bounce suppression list. Supports two deletion modes: bulk deletion of all bounced emails by setting `delete_all` to `true`, or selective deletion by specifying email addresses in the `emails` array. Note: `emails` and `delete_all` parameters are mutually exclusive - only one can be set per request. Returns success confirmation upon completion.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Delete bounces' is too generic and doesn't indicate the dual-mode functionality. Description lacks clarity about what is returned and doesn't explicitly state the mutual exclusivity constraint upfront. Enhanced summary specifies the operation supports both bulk and selective deletion. Enhanced description clarifies the mutually exclusive parameters, adds return value information, and improves AI agent understanding of when to use each deletion mode.

data.current_description: This endpoint will return the total number of bounces by classification in descending order for each day. You can retrieve the bounce classification totals in CSV format by specifying `"text/csv"` in the Accept header.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve bounce totals aggregated by classification
data.description_suggestion: Returns aggregated bounce statistics grouped by bounce classification type, sorted in descending order by count for each day. Supports multiple response formats: JSON (default) or CSV format by specifying `"text/csv"` in the Accept header. Useful for analyzing bounce patterns and trends across different classification categories to maintain sender reputation.
data.reasoning: Original summary lacks specificity about aggregation and time-series nature. Description doesn't explain the daily breakdown clearly or provide context about why this data is useful. Enhanced summary clarifies the aggregation by classification. Enhanced description adds format options clarity, explains the daily breakdown, and provides domain context about bounce classification analysis for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_summary: Retrieve bounce classification over time by domain stats
data.current_description: This endpoint will return the number of bounces for the classification specified in descending order for each day. You can retrieve the bounce classification totals in CSV format by specifying `"text/csv"` in the Accept header.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve bounce statistics for a specific classification
data.description_suggestion: Returns bounce statistics for a specific bounce classification type, aggregated daily and sorted in descending order by count. Provides time-series data showing bounce trends for the specified classification category. Supports multiple response formats: JSON (default) or CSV format by specifying `"text/csv"` in the Accept header. Use this to analyze bounce patterns for a particular classification type over time.
data.reasoning: Original summary is confusing - 'by domain stats' is unclear and doesn't match the actual operation which filters by classification parameter. Description doesn't clarify that this is a filtered view of a single classification. Enhanced summary clearly indicates filtering by classification. Enhanced description removes ambiguous 'domain' reference, clarifies the time-series nature, explains the classification parameter filtering, and provides context for AI agent understanding of when to use this versus the broader classifications endpoint.

data.current_summary: Search for suppressions within a group
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to search a suppression group for multiple suppressions.**

When given a list of email addresses and a group ID, this endpoint will only return the email addresses that have been unsubscribed from the given group.
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to search a suppression group to identify which email addresses have been unsubscribed from that group.**

Provide a list of email addresses and a group ID. The endpoint returns only those email addresses from your list that are currently suppressed (unsubscribed) from the specified group. This is useful for validating suppression status before sending campaigns or managing recipient lists.
data.reasoning: Description lacks clarity about the expected output format and practical use cases. Added explicit information about what is returned (filtered list of suppressed addresses), clarified the input requirements, and included context about when an AI agent should use this operation (validation, campaign management). This improves AI agent interpretability for determining when this operation is appropriate.

message: Operation 'ListAsmSuppression' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_output_details, missing_context. Original description is too minimal and lacks important context. Added clarification that this retrieves suppressions across all groups (not just one), mentioned pagination support (consistent with other list operations in the API), and explained what information is returned. This helps AI agents understand the scope and capabilities of this operation.

data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to retrieve a list of all suppressions.**
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a paginated list of all suppressed email addresses across all suppression groups.**

Returns all email addresses that have been globally suppressed or unsubscribed from any suppression group. The response includes suppression details and associated group information. Use pagination parameters to control result size and navigate through large suppression lists.
data.reasoning: Original description is too minimal and lacks important context. Added clarification that this retrieves suppressions across all groups (not just one), mentioned pagination support (consistent with other list operations in the API), and explained what information is returned. This helps AI agents understand the scope and capabilities of this operation.

data.current_summary: Retrieve all suppression groups for an email address
data.current_description: **This endpoint returns a list of all groups from which the given email address has been unsubscribed.**
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve suppression groups for an email address
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint returns a list of all suppression groups from which the given email address has been unsubscribed.**

Provide an email address to retrieve all groups where that address is currently suppressed. The response includes group IDs and names. This is useful for understanding a recipient's suppression status across your organization's different email categories.
data.reasoning: Summary was slightly redundant ('Retrieve all suppression groups' is clearer than 'Retrieve all suppression groups for'). Description lacked output details and practical context. Enhanced description clarifies what information is returned and provides use case context for AI agents to determine when this operation is appropriate.

message: Operation 'DeleteSuppressionBlocks' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details. Summary was too generic ('Delete blocks' is ambiguous). Enhanced to clarify that you're deleting blocked email addresses. Description needed clarification about the mutually exclusive nature of the two options and the side effect of deletion. Added context about what happens after deletion and when to use this operation, improving AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete all email addresses on your blocks list.**

There are two options for deleting blocked emails: 

1. You can delete all blocked emails by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body. 
2. You can delete a selection of blocked emails by specifying the email addresses in the `emails` array of the request body.
data.summary_suggestion: Delete blocked email addresses from blocks list
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to delete email addresses from your blocks list.**

There are two deletion options:

1. Delete all blocked emails by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body.
2. Delete specific blocked emails by providing an array of email addresses in the `emails` field of the request body.

Deleting a block removes the suppression, allowing emails to be sent to those addresses again. Ensure you only remove blocks for addresses that should receive your messages.
data.reasoning: Summary was too generic ('Delete blocks' is ambiguous). Enhanced to clarify that you're deleting blocked email addresses. Description needed clarification about the mutually exclusive nature of the two options and the side effect of deletion. Added context about what happens after deletion and when to use this operation, improving AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to retrieve a specific email address from your blocks list.**
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve block details for a specific email address.**

Provide an email address to check if it is currently on your blocks list and retrieve associated block information including the reason for blocking (e.g., bounce, spam report, invalid email). Returns block details if the address is blocked, or an error if the address is not on the blocks list.
data.reasoning: Summary is adequate but description lacks important details about what information is returned and the possible outcomes. Enhanced description clarifies what block details are included (reason for blocking), explains the different response scenarios, and provides context for when an AI agent should use this operation (checking block status before sending).

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to create a new suppression group.**

To add an email address to the suppression group, [create a Suppression](https://docs.sendgrid.com/api-reference/suppressions-suppressions/add-suppressions-to-a-suppression-group).
data.description_suggestion: Creates a new suppression group (also called an unsubscribe group or ASM group) that allows recipients to unsubscribe from specific categories of emails rather than all messages. Requires a request body with group name and optional description. Returns the created suppression group object with its assigned group ID. After creation, use the Add Suppressions endpoint to add email addresses to this group.
data.reasoning: Original summary uses generic 'suppression group' terminology. Description lacks clarity on what the operation returns, the purpose of suppression groups, and required inputs. Added domain context about ASM groups, explained the business purpose, clarified return value, and mentioned the next logical step for AI agent workflow.

data.current_summary: Retrieve all suppression groups associated with the user.
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a list of all suppression groups created by this user.**

This endpoint can also return information for multiple group IDs that you include in your request. To add a group ID to your request, simply append `?id=123456&id=123456`, with the appropriate group IDs.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all suppression groups (unsubscribe groups) created by the authenticated user. Supports filtering by specific group IDs using query parameters (e.g., ?id=123456&id=789012). Returns an array of suppression group objects, each containing group ID, name, description, and suppression count. Useful for discovering available groups or checking group configurations.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and actionable. Description lacks clarity on what is returned and the structure of the response. Added information about return value structure, clarified the filtering mechanism, and explained the use case for AI agent decision-making.

Use this operation to verify group configuration or check the number of suppressed addresses in a specific group.

data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to update or change a suppression group.**
data.description_suggestion: Updates the name and/or description of an existing suppression group. Accepts a request body with the fields to be modified (name and/or description). Supports partial updates - only provided fields will be changed. Returns the updated suppression group object with all current properties. Use this to rename groups or update their descriptions without affecting suppressed addresses.

message: Operation 'DeleteAsmGroup' has semantic quality issues: missing_side_effects, not_actionable. Summary is generic and doesn't convey the significant side effects. Description buries critical information about suppressions being lifted. Restructured to clearly highlight the destructive nature of this operation and its consequences, making it more actionable for AI agents to understand when this operation should be used.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a suppression group.**

If a recipient uses the "one-click unsubscribe" option on an email associated with a deleted group, that recipient will be added to the global suppression list.

Deleting a suppression group will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed addresses. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.
data.summary_suggestion: Delete a suppression group and lift suppressions
data.description_suggestion: Deletes a suppression group (unsubscribe group) by its group ID. IMPORTANT SIDE EFFECTS: (1) All email addresses previously suppressed by this group will be removed from suppression, and emails will resume being sent to those addresses; (2) If recipients use one-click unsubscribe on emails associated with this deleted group, they will be added to the global suppression list instead. This operation should only be performed if recipients have explicitly requested to receive emails again. Use bypass filters if you need to send to specific suppressed addresses without deleting the group.
data.reasoning: Summary is generic and doesn't convey the significant side effects. Description buries critical information about suppressions being lifted. Restructured to clearly highlight the destructive nature of this operation and its consequences, making it more actionable for AI agents to understand when this operation should be used.

message: Operation 'AddSuppressionToAsmGroup' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary is acceptable. Description lacks clarity on inputs (array of emails), outputs (201 status), and the critical side effect about non-existent groups. Restructured to explain the request format, clarify the response, and prominently highlight the fallback behavior to global suppressions for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_summary: Add suppressions to a suppression group
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to add email addresses to an unsubscribe group.**

If you attempt to add suppressions to a group that has been deleted or does not exist, the suppressions will be added to the global suppressions list.
data.description_suggestion: Adds one or more email addresses to a suppression group (unsubscribe group), marking them as suppressed for that specific category. Accepts a request body containing an array of email addresses to suppress. Returns a 201 status on success. IMPORTANT: If the target group has been deleted or does not exist, the email addresses will be added to the global suppression list instead, suppressing them from all emails. Use this operation to suppress addresses from specific email categories or to bulk-suppress addresses after identifying them as unengaged.
data.reasoning: Summary is acceptable. Description lacks clarity on inputs (array of emails), outputs (201 status), and the critical side effect about non-existent groups. Restructured to explain the request format, clarify the response, and prominently highlight the fallback behavior to global suppressions for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_summary: Retrieve all suppressions for a suppression group
data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to retrieve all suppressed email addresses belonging to the given group.**
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves all email addresses currently suppressed in a specific suppression group by its group ID. Returns an array of suppressed email address objects, each containing the email address and the date it was added to the suppression group. Supports pagination for groups with large numbers of suppressions. Use this to audit which addresses are suppressed in a specific category or to verify suppression status.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and actionable. Description is too minimal and doesn't explain the response structure or pagination support. Added details about what is returned, mentioned pagination capability, and provided use cases to help AI agents understand when and how to use this operation.
